content: In February 2002, the Bush Administration proposed "Clear Skies" to amend the Clean Air Act by placing emission caps on electric utility emissions of SO2, NOx, and Hg. The caps would be imposed in two phases: 2010 (2008 for NOx) and 2018. Clear Skies was introduced in the 108th Congress as H.R. 999 and S. 485, and a modified version was introduced in the 109th Congress as S. 131. The Clear Skies proposal introduced emission caps on electric utility emissions of SO2, NOx, and Hg in two phases: 2010 (2008 for NOx) and 2018. A modified version was introduced in the 109th Congress as S. 131 by Senator Inhofe, focusing on a cap-and-trade implementation scheme. EPA states that Clear Skies would deliver guaranteed emissions reductions at a fraction of command and control costs. The Clear Skies proposal focuses on a cap-and-trade implementation scheme for reducing emissions of SO2, NOx, and mercury.
